DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Try to Roll Back Election Reform
DOC.TEXT: Conservatives on Monday tried to roll back political reform with an attempt to restore the Communist Party's 100 guaranteed seats in the Congress of People's Deputies. The Congress' legislative arm, the Supreme Soviet, voted several months ago to remove a section of the Constitution allocating one-third of the 2,250 Congressional seats to certain social organizations, including the Communist Party and the Young Communist League, known as the Komsomol. Instead, all deputies would have to face public election in a territorial district. The constitutional change must be confirmed by the full Congress, however, and that is where representatives of the organizations fought to keep their privileged position. If the reform wins final approval, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would have to run in his first election campaign in 1994 if he wants to retain the presidency when his current five-year term expires. He would have to run only in one local district, like British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, because the Congress elects the president from among its members. Although a vote was taken on the issue Monday, many deputies were confused, and they wound up sending the issue back to committee overnight. Some deputies apparently thought the 1,740 to 98 decision meant social organizations would lose their seats, while other deputies thought it meant just the opposite. The decision will affect both the national Congress and the parliaments of the republics. Most republics chose direct, territorial elections, but Byelorussia and Kazakhstan already have begun nominations from social organizations. Deputy Anatoly Sobchak said the system of electing deputies from social organizations violated ``the most important principle of election rights _ the principle of one man, one vote.'' Under this system, for example, a female Communist scientist could vote for deputies representing the Communist Party, the Academy of Sciences, the national women's society and the district where she lives. Many deputies representing such organizations took the microphone to argue the system should remain in place. Many claimed it was necessary to guarantee representation of invalids, the Red Cross and other relief organizations. They did not mention that the primary beneficiary of the system is the Communist Party. An exasperated Sobchak responded, ``Don't make our country the laughingstock of the world. I fear that if we take this decison, arguing that it will help invalids, then people will begin to call us an invalid state.'' Deputy Ilya Zaslavsky, who walks with a cane and was elected on a program of invalids' rights, argued that many organizations were not even on the list guaranteed representation in the Congress. Therefore, he argued, all organizations should compete for seats in territorial-based elections.
